title: Fears of a Japan debt crisis dismissed as share markets soar | The Business | ABC NEWS
description: The promise of tax cuts and additional cost of living measures which propelled Japan's prime minister to a historic landslide victory have seen the Japanese share market soar. Its economy - the fifth largest in the world - is consequential for the global economy and markets.  Blackrock's head of active equity for Japan, Yue Bamba joined The Business from Tokyo. He says the weekend result creates some stability in the world's political system. He says fears of a Japanese debt crisis is unwarranted, because even though the country's debt-to-GDP is elevated, it's decreasing.  He says he believes Sanae Takaichi and her government will be 'sensible' in running the economy.   Bond and FX markets have reacted positively, as well as the Yen 'holding up remarkably well', he said.  "The market is reacting in such a way, especially the long end of the interest rate curve, because that (instability) in the long end of the GDP curve could have had ripple effects to the rest of the world," he says.  #ABCBusiness Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. It's news when you want it, from Australia's most trusted news organisation. title: Hong Kong media mogul and China critic sentenced to 20 years in prison | ABC NEWS
description: Prominent Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai is likely to spend life in prison after being sentenced to 20 years. An outspoken critic of Beijing, he was charged under China's national security laws. The Australian government has expressed serious concern, stating that the case will have a chilling effect on free speech. title: Liberals despair at prospect of 'non-existence', weigh leadership change | ABC NEWS
description: Liberals are openly canvassing the prospect of a leadership spill by week's end with a disastrous opinion poll pointing to the party's electoral wipe-out. For now, Sussan Ley says she maintains the party's support, but Angus Taylor's backers are plotting their move. National affairs correspondent Jane Norman reports. title: Israeli President Herzog visits Sydney as thousands protest | ABC NEWS
description: Israeli President Isaac Herzog visited Sydney amid massive security. He met with families of victims from the Bondi terrorist attack targeting Jews and suggested more could have been done to prevent it. Meanwhile, thousands protested his visit in Sydney's CBD, despite the Palestinian Action Group losing a legal challenge against expanded police powers. title: ASIO told of Bondi shooter's terror links years ago, ex-spy claims | ABC NEWS
description: A Four Corners investigation has revealed an undercover agent shared intelligence with Australia's spy agency ASIO about the alleged radicalisation of the Bondi attackers six years before the massacre. ASIO says it investigated the intelligence but couldn't substantiate it and it stands by its assessment at the time. The revelations add to questions about intelligence failures in the lead-up to the Bondi attack. Sean Rubinsztein-Dunlop from ABC Investigations has this exclusive report. title: Why young workers could get a pay boost | The Business | ABC NEWS
description: Hardworking young people are closely watching a key wage case that could boost their pay, while businesses warn it could cause a collapse in employment. "Junior pay rates" apply to people below the age of 21 in agreements covering sectors that employ a lot of young people in retail, fast food and pharmacy.  Those discounts mean 18-year-olds are paid 70 per cent of the award rate, 80 per cent for 19-year-olds and 90 per cent for 20-year-olds.  The Fair Work Commission has finished hearings but has not announced when it will hand down its decision. Advocates argue that at 17 you can enlist in the armed forces, and at 18 you are legally entitled to vote, drive, smoke and drink alcohol.  Ai Group's Innes Willox says any big shift that increases staff costs will have dire consequences for young people. "Young people won't be hired for jobs, and that will be to the detriment of them," he said.  Sally McManus, secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions compared the cheaper rates paid to juniors — and employers' fears of change — to the situation more than 50 years ago, when paying women less for doing the same work as men was first outlawed.  #ABCBusiness Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE Read more here: https://www.abc.net.au/news/2026-02-09/millions-of-young-people-could-get-massive-pay-boost-in-totemic/106101186  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. description: The Australian man who shot dead 51 people at two mosques in the Christchurch terrorist attack has appeared in court in an attempt to vacate his guilty pleas. title: First Greens politician quits NT parliament after 18 months | ABC NEWS
description: The first Greens politician in the Northern Territory parliament has announced her resignation, 18 months after beating former chief minister Natasha Fyles to win the seat of Nightcliff.   Kat McNamara is leaving the job effectively immediately, triggering what's set to be a hotly contested byelection. Jack Hislop reports for ABC News Northern Territory. title: Thai PM Anutin vows to build Cambodia border wall after election win | The World | ABC News
description: Thailand's caretaker prime minister Anutin Charnvirakul says he is confident that he has enough parliamentary seats to form government as his conservative Bhumjaithai Party leads a three-way race in the general election count. The country went to the polls on Sunday in a tight race between conservatives aligned with the military and the monarchy, and progressive elements represented by the reform-driven People's Party. Underscoring the role that nationalism played in the vote, Anutin also vowed to build a wall ‌along Thailand's border with Cambodia and strengthen the military. The World's Girish Sawlani spoke with Khaosod English senior reporter Pravit Rojanaphruk about what was behind the surge in support for the Bhumjaithai Party. title: Japan election: How Sanae Takaichi orchestrated LDP's historic landslide win | The World | ABC News
description: Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi's coalition swept to a historic election win on Sunday. The conservative Ms Takaichi, who said she was inspired by Britain's 'Iron Lady', Margaret Thatcher, was projected to deliver as many as 328 of the 465 seats in parliament's lower house for her Liberal Democratic Party. The World's Girish Sawlani spoke to Dr Jeff Hall from Kanda University of International Studies about the main factors behind the LDP's huge win. title: Thailand's ruling party secures unexpected election victory | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Thailand's caretaker prime minister Anutin Charnvirakul looks set to clinch a decisive victory in the country's general election. His conservative Bhumjaithai Party couldn't claim an outright majority, but is likely to lead a coalition government. The result came as a surprise to supporters of the popular People's Party, who were expected to win the most votes. Rebecca Johnston reports. title: UK's Prince William and Princess Kate 'deeply concerned' by Epstein files | The World | ABC NEWS
description: The Prince and Princess of Wales have just issued a statement, saying they're deeply concerned about the latest revelations from the Epstein files. Prince William and Princess Kate say they were focused on the victims, in their first public statement on the issue. It comes as the leadership of UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer is under pressure after his chief of staff resigned over his role in the appointment of Lord Mandelson as ambassador to the US, despire his publicly-known relationship with Jeffrey Epstein. Tim Bale is Professor of Politics at Queen Mary University of London and spoke to The World's Girish Sawlani.
